Indications and doses

Staphylococcal bone and joint infections such as osteomyelitis, Peritonitis, Intra-abdominal sepsis, Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in bronchiectasis, bone and joint infections, and skin and soft-tissue infections, Erysipelas or cellulitis in penicillin-allergic patients (alternative to macrolides),

By deep intramuscular injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    150–300 mg every 6 hours; increased if necessary up to 450 g every 6 hours if required, increased dose used in severe infection.
  • For adults
    0.6–2.7 g daily in 2–4 divided doses; increased if necessary up to 4.8 g daily, increased dose used in life-threatening infection, single doses above 600 mg to be administered by intravenous infusion only, single doses by intravenous infusion not to exceed 1.2 g.
  • For children
    3–6 mg/kg 4 times a day (max. per dose 450 mg).

Treatment of mild to moderate pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with primaquine),

By mouth

  • For adults
    600 mg every 8 hours.

Treatment of falciparum malaria (to be given with or following quinine),

By mouth

  • For adults
    450 mg every 8 hours for 7 days.
  • For children
    7–13 mg/kg every 8 hours (max. per dose 450 mg) for 7 days.

Drug action

Clindamycin is active against Gram-positive cocci, including streptococci and penicillin-resistant staphylococci, and also against many anaerobes, especially Bacteroides fragilis . It is well concentrated in bone and excreted in bile and urine.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Not known to be harmful.

Contra indications

  • Diarrhoeal states

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Abdominal discomfort, anaphylactoid reactions, antibiotic-associated colitis, diarrhoea (discontinue treatment), eosinophilia, exfoliative dermatitis, jaundice, leucopenia, nausea, oesophageal ulcers, oesophagitis, polyarthritis, pruritus, rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, taste disturbances, thrombocytopenia, toxic epidermal necrolysis, urticaria, vesiculobullous dermatitis, vomiting,

Specific side effects

notKnown: induration (after intramuscular injection), abscess (after intramuscular injection), pain (after intramuscular injection), thrombophlebitis (after intravenous injection),

Antibiotic-associated colitis

Clindamycin has been associated with antibiotic-associated colitis, which may be fatal. Although antibiotic-associated colitis can occur with most antibacterials, it occurs more frequently with clindamycin. Patients should therefore discontinue treatment immediately if diarrhoea develops.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use

Avoid rapid intravenous administration.

With intravenous use in children

For intravenous infusion, dilute to a concentration of not more than 18 mg/mL with Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%; give over 10–60 minutes at a max. rate of 20 mg/kg/hour.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Dalacin C Phosphate), give continuously or intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%; dilute to not more than 18 mg/mL and give over 10–60 minutes at a rate not exceeding 30 mg/minute (1.2 g over at least 60 minutes; higher doses by continuous infusion).

Advice for patients and carers

Patients and their carers should be advised to discontinue immediately and contact doctor if diarrhoea develops.

With oral use

Capsules should be swallowed with a glass of water.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Avoid in Acute porphyrias
  • : middle-aged and elderly women, especially after an operation (antibiotic-associated colitis more common) in adults

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor liver and renal function if treatment exceeds 10 days.

In children

Monitor liver and renal function in neonates and infants.

Unlicensed use

In adults

Not licensed for treatment of mild to moderate pneumocystis infection.

Not licensed for treatment of falciparum malaria.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Clindamycin Capsules may be prescribed.

Prepared medicinal forms of CLINDAMYCIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.
